Teoretické základy evolvabiltních softwarových systémů: stabilita systému, normalizované systémy
System is Normalized (Stable) if any Combinatorial Ripple Effects are prevented
Teoretické základy evolvabiltních softwarových systémů: kombinatorický efekt, problematika modularity

Combinatorial effects are instabilities caused by ripple effects.
Example: Change Ripples: The Saturn V:
To Increase thrust power: Add additional F1, Additional fuel line, More powerful fuel pump, Larger fuel tank stage 1, Stronger fuel tank stage 1, Adapt shape fuel tank stage 1, Enlarge interstage & second stage, Adapt interstage & second stage...
-> Design new rocket
Historie přístupu k evolvabilitě softwarových systémů.

The First Generation
Assumptions: From-scratch development, Insourcing, Requirements can be developed up front
Paradigm: Structured development
Process: Waterfall model (Royce, 1970)The Second Generation
Paradigm: Object orientation (object = combination of data and process)
Principles: Encapsulation/information hiding, Inheritance
Notation: Consolidation of notation: Booch, Rumbaugh, Jacobson define UML
Assumptions: “The” method does not exist, Reuse is of primary importance, Requirements change quickly
Process: Iterative development, Unified Process (RUP)
Use Case-driven development methodology
Design Patterns (Gamma et al., 1995)
